19.46.text:
Well, hello. We must get on, it's Shrove Tuesday
and there's Pancakes to make.

27.08.text: So to begin you will need.

45.25.text:
I am going to whisk my eggs in my trusty copper
bowl. Copper bowls are very good for whisking

66.74.text:
eggs. You'll find that your eggs will whisk
much quicker and in a much firmer way.

73.82.text:
And then we're going to add some milk. I would
recommend to roughly three eggs to start by

83.75.text:
adding a quarter. And now three tablespoons
of flour to be added gradually.

93.80.text:
You want to make sure that you don't get any
lumps. And then I'll add my other two. And

113.44.text: there we have the batter for your Pancakes.

120.99.text:
So the first thing you need to do is to make
sure you've got a nice even fire so your pan

128.48.text:
is evenly hot. And then you can add the butter.
If your not an experience cook and a little

135.66.text:
bit nervous of flipping your pancake, make
sure you put in only a small amount of mix

140.58.text:
to make to a nice thin Pancake, and then you
wont have to turn it over.

152.40.text:
If you want a slightly thicker Pancake and
you want to cook both sides then the easiest

156.66.text: way to turn it over is to flip it.

163.43.text: A nice clean way to turn the Pancake over.

167.46.text:
These ones are going to go to the servants.
There are plenty of them so I've got a lot

172.37.text:
Keep them warm in front of a fire until they
are ready to serve.

176.36.text:
I've taken more time over these ones. They're
for Lord and Lady Braybrooke and between each

181.27.text:
layer I have either sprinkled sugar or I've
spread some apricot jam.

188.76.text:
Layer that on, the final one, and then a sprinkling
of sugar.

200.75.text:
You can serve it to the top table then with
perhaps some clotted cream or any other bits

205.37.text:
that you choose. We have Pancakes for Lord
and Lady Braybrooke and for us servants.

210.99.text: A good way to begin Lent.
